'''Christopher Abad''' is an [[United States|American]] [[Hacker (computer security)|hacker]], [[museum]] [[curator]], [[artist]], network engineer and [[programmer]]. He is best known for his qualitative analysis of specialization stratification in the underground economies related to [[computer crime]].
==Academic publication and mainstream news coverage== While at [[UCLA]], Abad discovered a method by which collisions in the [[hash function]] used in [[Internet Protocol]] datagrams may be leveraged to enable [[covert]] channel communications.<ref name="hash_coll">{{Citation | last = Abad | first = Christopher | author-link = | publication-date = | date = | year = 2001 | title = IP Checksum Covert Channels and Selected Hash Collision | periodical = | series = | publication-place = | place = | publisher = | volume = | issue = | pages = 3 | at = | format=PDF | url = http://www.gray-world.net/papers/ipccc.pdf | accessdate = 2010-10-08 }}</ref> His discovery was a centerpiece of covert communications methodology and was the primary citation for an [[Association for Computing Machinery]] paper on covert channel detection<ref name="acm1">http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.84.6196&rep=rep1&type=pdf</ref> and another on a similar technique using [[Transmission Control Protocol|TCP]] [[timestamp]]s,<ref name="acm2">http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.104.2501&rep=rep1&type=pdf</ref> the two most well-cited and widely republished papers on the subject.
In 2005 while working at [[Cloudmark]], Abad spent six months examining the phishing underworld from the inside.<ref name="onlinewsj1">{{cite news |title=Phisher Tales: How Webs of Scammers Pull Off Internet Fraud |first=Lee |last=Gomes |newspaper=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |date=2005-06-20 |url=http://online.wsj.com/public/article/SB111922540322063658-k2iziFe2OaO0z3gRtu_AvHbEtKk_20060620.html |accessdate=2010-10-08}}</ref> Abad discovered that phishers were using [[IRC]] channels in order to trade personal information.<ref name="infomationweek1">{{cite news |title=Researcher Describes How The Phishing Economy Works |first=Gregg |last=Keizer |newspaper=[[InformationWeek]] |date=2005-07-29 |url=http://www.informationweek.com/news/security/vulnerabilities/showArticle.jhtml?articleID=166403892 |accessdate=2010-10-08}}</ref> He stalked and collected messages from thirteen chat rooms phishers use.<ref name="infomationweek1"/> Whereas past phishing researchers believed that phishing was coordinated by highly organized criminals, Abad discovered that phishing rings were decentralized.<ref name="infomationweek1"/> Abad published his findings in [[First Monday (journal)|First Monday]].<ref>{{cite journal |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |year=2005 |title=The economy of phishing: A survey of the operations of the phishing market |journal=[[First Monday (journal)|First Monday]] |publisher= |volume=10 |issue=9 |pages= |url=http://firstmonday.org/htbin/cgiwrap/bin/ojs/index.php/fm/article/view/1272/1192 |doi= }}</ref> This paper was the first examination of how the economy of [[phishing]] agents functioned, and highlighted the high degree of specialization within the economy.
==20 GOTO 10== Abad is the founder and owner<ref name=lee>Lee, Ellen. [http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2008/01/12/BUBFUD235.DTL Early computer-generated art revived for S.F. exhibit]. ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]''. 12 Jan 2008.</ref> of [[20 GOTO 10]], a gallery which caters not only to [[fine art]], but to "[[Hacker (computer security)|hacker]]" art, with an emphasis on [[technology]] as art, or exhibits which make the potentially criminal or unethical aspects of computer security accessible to the public.<ref>McMillan, Robert ([[International Data Group|IDG]] News service)[http://www.itworld.com/Tech/2987/071030hackerart/ San Francisco gallery shows hacker Joe Grand's work as art] [http://www.pcworld.com/businesscenter/article/138991/san_francisco_gallery_shows_hackers_work_as_art.html 2] ''[[PC World (magazine)|PC World]]'', ''[[IT World]]''</ref> The gallery received many favorable reviews coverage for its airing of art related to the computer underground, including [[ANSI]]<ref>Johnson, Joel. [http://gadgets.boingboing.net/2008/01/28/ansi-art-show-at-20.html ANSI Art Show at 20 GOTO 10 Gallery] ''[[Boing Boing]]''. 28 Jan 2008.</ref> and [[Stereoscopy|3D]]<ref>Hart, Hugh. [http://www.wired.com/underwire/2008/07/art-geek-create/ Art Geek Creates 3-D on a Shoestring]''[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]''. 9 Jul 2008.</ref> art.
